Name: Thomas P. Tammen
Title: Thomas P. Tammen file
Description: File documenting the participation of Thomas P. Tammen in World War I. Tammen enlisted on December 28, 1917, and received training at the Marine Corps Recruit Depot at Parris Island, South Carolina. He transferred to Quantico, Virginia, before being sent overseas on September 23, 1918, with the 13th Marine Corps. He was stationed at the Church of St. Sulpice in Paris, France. Tammen returned to the states on July 31, 1919. File includes letters and an RSVP card. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Marine Corps; Parris Island (S.C. : Recruit depot); United States. Marine Corps. Marine Regiment, 13th
Topics: Tammen, Thomas P.; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Glenn S. Tatman
Location: Great Lakes Naval Training Center (Great Lakes, Ill.)
Title: Glenn S. Tatman file
Description: File documenting the participation of Glenn S. Tatman in World War I. Tatman enlisted in May 1918 and was first stated at Great Lakes Naval Training Center in Illinois. He was sent overseas in July 1918 and was based at the naval aviation base in Paulliac, France, as a carpenters mate. He was stationed in Tergnier, France, in November 1918, when the armistice was signed. Tatman was among the first soldiers to be sent back to the States on November 16, 1918. File includes newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Navy;
Topics: Tatman, Glenn S.; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Horton E. Tatman
Title: Horton E. Tatman file
Description: File documenting the participation of Horton E. Tatman in World War I. Tatman enlisted in the Navy on May 16, 1917, and was first stationed at Norfolk, Virginia. He was transferred to Pensacola, Florida, on August 2, 1917, to be a carpenters mate. He was sent overseas on October 28, 1917, and was stationed in Montrichard, France, on November 3, 1917. He was at the 7th Army Aviation Instruction Center at the Clermont-Ferrand Aerodrome on May 28, 1918, and then transferred to the Navy Headquarters in Paris, France, on July 12, 1918. He joined the Army's 217th Aero Squadron on July 22, 1918, and on October 1, 1918, he joined the Marine Air Force. He returned to the States on December 15, 1918, and was stationed at Hampton Roads Naval Base until February 1, 1919. He remained in the service after the war. Tatman died May 3, 1923, while stationed in San Diego, California, in an airplane accident. File includes an RSVP card, letters, and newspaper clippings. Description supplemented by information from Ancestry.com.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Navy; United States. Naval Aviation Corps; United States. Army; United States. Army. Air Service; United States. Army. Air Service. Aero Squadron, 217th; United States. Marine Corps; United States. Marine Aviation Force;
Topics: Tatman, Horton Edward, 1891-1923; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Earl Robert Taubeneck
Title: Earl Robert Taubeneck file
Description: File documenting the participation of Earl Robert Taubeneck in World War I. Taubeneck served in the Aviation Signal Service Corps with the 33rd Spruce Squadron. The Spruce Squadron was responsible for chopping down trees in Sultan, Washington, for the construction of ships and airplanes. He was later stationed in Neodesha, Kansas, in April 1919. File includes a survey, letters, an envelope, and newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Signal Corps. Aviation Section; United States. Army. Air Service; United States. Army. Air Service. Aero Squadron, 416th; United States. Army. Spruce Squadron, 33rd

Name: Ignatius Donnelly Taubeneck
Title: Ignatius Donnelly Taubeneck file
Description: File documenting the participation of Ignatius Donnelly Taubeneck in World War I. Taubeneck enlisted on March 28, 1918, and first served at Camp Shelby, Mississippi, with the 15th Machine Gun Co. He joined the 152nd Machine Gun Co. on June 21, 1918. He was sent overseas on October 6, 1918, with the 58th Infantry, and stationed in the Metz sector in France. He participated in the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. After the armistice was signed, he was stationed in Neuenahr and Koblenz, Germany. Taubeneck returned to the States on August 1, 1919, and was discharged August 8, 1919. File includes two surveys, a photo, letters, and newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Machine Gun Battalion, 15th; United States. Army. Machine Gun Battalion, 152nd; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 58th
Topics: Taubeneck, Ignatius Donnelly; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

He was sent overseas on October 6, 1918, with the 58th Infantry, and stationed in the Metz sector in France. He participated in the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. After the armistice was signed, he was stationed in Neuenahr and Koblenz, Germany. Taubeneck returned to the States on August 1, 1919, and was discharged August 8, 1919. File includes two surveys, a photo, letters, and newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Machine Gun Battalion, 15th; United States. Army. Machine Gun Battalion, 152nd; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 58th
Topics: Taubeneck, Ignatius Donnelly; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Arthur Cullen Taylor
Title: Arthur Cullen Taylor file
Description: File documenting the participation of Arthur Cullen Taylor in World War I. Taylor enlisted on May 23, 1917, and was first stationed at Camp Columbia in Cincinnati, Ohio, as an instructor with the 1st Ohio Infantry. He transferred to Camp Sheridan, Alabama, in November 1917 to be an instructor in the 158th Infantry. Taylor was discharged on January 13, 1918, after an injury that caused paralysis in one leg. He regained limited leg use and became a civilian instructor at the Air Services School at Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, until February 19, 1919. File includes a survey, letter, and newspaper clipping.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Ohio Infantry Regiment, 1st; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 158th; Carnegie Institute of Technology
Topics: Taylor, Arthur Cullen; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Title: Raymond Carl Theis file
Description: File documenting the participation of Raymond Carl Theis in World War I. Name: Robert Shelton Thomas
Title: Robert Shelton Thomas file
Description: File documenting the participation of Robert Shelton Thomas in World War I. Thomas enlisted on August 4, 1918, and was first stationed at the Marine Corps Recruit Depot in Parris Island, South Carolina. He joined the Rifle Detail in September 1918. He transferred to Quantico, Virginia, to join the Norfolk Detail in December 1918. He joined the 160th Company in Portsmouth, Virginia, until his discharge on February 18, 1919. File includes a survey, photos, a letter, and newspaper clippings.

Title: Kenneth A. Thompson file
Description: File documenting the participation of Kenneth A. Thompson in World War I. Name: Lee E. Thompson
Title: Lee E. Thompson file
Description: File documenting the participation of Lee E. Thompson in World War I. Thomspon enlisted on May 14, 1917, and was first stationed at Fort Sheridan, Illinois, with the Reserve Officers' Training Corps. He transferred to Camp Grant, Illinois, to join the 343rd Infantry on September 1, 1917. On June 1, 1918, he was sent to Camp Pike, Arkansas, to be a lieutenant with the Infantry Replacement Camp. He joined the Small Arms Firing School at Camp Perry, Ohio, on July 1, 1918. He transferred to Camp Zachary Taylor on August 20, 1918, to be a lieutenant with the 159th Depot Brigade. Thompson was discharged on December 12, 1918. File includes a survey, letter, and newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Reserve Officers' Training Corps; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 343rd; Small Arms Firing School (Camp Perry, Ohio); United States. Army. Depot Brigade, 159th
Topics: Thompson, Lee E.; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Josiah Norris Throgmorton
Title: Josiah Norris Throgmorton file
Description: File documenting the participation of Josiah Norris Throgmorton in World War I. Throgmorton enlisted on October 3, 1917, and was first stationed in Camp Zachary Taylor, Kentucky, with the Machine Gun Corps. He joined the 309th Military Police in April 1918, and was transferred to Camp Sherman, Ohio. He was sent overseas on September 9, 1918, with the 309th Engineers and was stationed at Le Havre, France, and Montoir, France. Throgmorton returned to the States in July 1919. File includes a photo, postcards, letters, and newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Military Police Battalion, 309th; United States. Army. Engineer Regiment, 309th

Name: William Gilbert Tice
Title: William Gilbert Tice file
Description: File documenting the participation of William Gilbert Tice in World War I. Tice enlisted on December 10, 1917 and was first stationed in Belleville, Illinois, with the 222nd Aero Squadron. He joined the 155th Aero Squadron on January 16, 1919, and was sent overseas on February 16, 1918. He was stationed at Eaton Place in London for several months before being sent to several locations in France: La Havre, Neufchateau, and Toul. He was sent back to the States on March 4, 1919. Tice remained at Camp Grant, Illinois, until his discharge on December 7, 1919. File includes a survey, photos, postcards, RSVP card, letters, newspaper clippings, and his marriage announcement. File supplemented by information from Fold3.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Air Service; United States. Army. Air Service. Aero Squadron, 222nd; United States. Army. Air Service. Aero Squadron, 155th
Topics: Tice, William Gilbert; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students
Genre/format: questionnaires; photographs; postcards; reply cards; letters (correspondence); newspaper clippings; wedding announcements;

Name: Clyde Loughridge Todd
Title: Clyde Loughridge Todd file
Description: File documenting the participation of Clyde Loughridge Todd in World War I. Todd enlisted on August 1, 1917, and was first stationed at the Marine Corps Recruit Depot at Parris Island, South Carolina. He transferred to Quantico, Virginia, in February 1918, and was sent overseas on March 13, 1918. He joined the 6th Marines while in France. He participated in the battles at Belleau Woods, Soissons, St. Mihiel, Blanc Mont Ridge and St Etienne, and the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. He was hospitalized twice. From July 19, 1918, to August 10, 1918, he was at the Toul, France, Base Hosptial no. 27 from shrapnel wounds to his shoulder and arm. From November 4, 1918, to December 12, 1918, he was at Base Hosptial no. 41 in Paris for a shrapnel wound in his ankle. Todd left France on December 25, 1918, and was discharged at Quantico, Virginia, on April 14, 1919. File includes a survey, photo, postcards, RSVP card, and letters. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Marine Corps; Parris Island (S.C. : Recruit depot); United States. Marine Corps. Marine Regiment, 6th
Topics: Todd, Clyde Loughridge; Belleau Wood, Battle of, France, 1918; Soissons, Battle of, Soissons, France, 1918; Saint-Mihiel, Battle of, Saint-Mihiel, France, 1918; Blanc Mont Ridge, Battle of, France, 1918; Saint-Etienne, Battle of, Saint-Etinne, France, 1918; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

He participated in the battles at Belleau Woods, Soissons, St. Mihiel, Blanc Mont Ridge and St Etienne, and the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. He was hospitalized twice. From July 19, 1918, to August 10, 1918, he was at the Toul, France, Base Hosptial no. 27 from shrapnel wounds to his shoulder and arm. From November 4, 1918, to December 12, 1918, he was at Base Hosptial no. 41 in Paris for a shrapnel wound in his ankle. Todd left France on December 25, 1918, and was discharged at Quantico, Virginia, on April 14, 1919. File includes a survey, photo, postcards, RSVP card, and letters. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Marine Corps; Parris Island (S.C. : Recruit depot); United States. Marine Corps. Marine Regiment, 6th

Title: Lawrence Edward Toole file
Description: File documenting the participation of Lawrence Edward Toole in World War I. Toole enlisted on March 25, 1918, and was first stationed at Fort Terry, New York, with the 21st Coast Artillery Corps. He joined the 68th Coast Artillery Corps on June 1, 1918. Name: Clarence Edward Townsend
Title: Clarence Edward Townsend file
Description: File documenting the participation of Clarence Edward Townsend in World War I. Townsend enlisted on October 3, 1917, and was first stationed at Camp Taylor, Kentucky, with the 327th Field Artillery. He joined the 333rd Infantry on March 3, 1918. He was sent overseas on September 1, 1918, and was stationed at Camp Hosptial no. 48 as a surgical assistant in Recy, France, on December 1, 1918. He returned to the States on June 30, 1919, and was discharged on July 9, 1919. File includes a survey.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Medical Department; United States. Army. Field Artillery Regiment, 327th; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 333rd

Name: Lawrence A. Twomey
Title: Lawrence A. Twomey file
Description: File documenting the participation of Lawrence A. Twomey in World War I. Twomey enlisted on October 15, 1917, and was first stationed at Allentown, Pennsylvania, with the Army Ambulance Service. He was sent overseas on June 12, 1918, and was stationed in Genoa, Italy. He also served with the Italian Army Section 603. He participated in the Battle of Vittorio Veneto in Italy. Twomey left for the States on April 8, 1919, and was discharged on April 29, 1919. File includes a survey, photo, postcards, letter, newspaper clippings, and RSVP card.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Ambulance Corps; Italy. Esercito
Topics: Twomey, Lawrence A.; Vittorio Veneto, Battle of, Vittorio Veneto, Italy, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Henry Elton Underbrink
Title: Henry Elton Underbrink file
Description: File documenting the participation of Henry Elton Underbrink in World War I. Underbrink enlisted on May 30, 1918, and was first stationed at Camp Dodge, Iowa, with the 163rd Depot Brigade. He joined the 313rd Engineers on June 30, 1918. He was sent overseas on August 13, 1918, and participated in the Haute-Alsace sector engagement (in what is currently known as the Grand Est region). Underbrink left for the States on May 25, 1919, and was discharged on June 18, 1919. File includes a survey and photo.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Depot Brigade, 163rd; United States. Army. Engineer Regiment, 313th

Name: Julia Scott Vrooman
Title: Julia Scott Vrooman file
Description: File documenting the participation of Julia Scott Vrooman in World War I. Vrooman joined the entertainment division of the Y.M.C.A. on August 23, 1918. She was sent overseas with her husband upon entering the service and was stationed in Paris, France. She organized the jazz band for the Y.M.C.A. After the armistice was signed, she was stationed in Mayen, Germany. She returned to the States on September 12, 1919, and was released from service the same day. File includes a survey, Vrooman's service record card, photos, a letter, newspaper clippings, and a booklet she wrote.
Related organization/service branch: YMCA of the USA
Topics: Vrooman, Julia Scott; Bands (Music); World War, 1914-1918;
Genre/format: questionnaires; cards (information artifacts); photographs; letters (correspondence); newspaper clippings; booklets;

Name: William Samuel Wallace
Title: William Samuel Wallace file
Description: File documenting the participation of William Samuel Wallace in World War I. Wallace joined the Y.M.C.A. on August 31, 1917, and was sent overseas on October 31, 1917. He was made the business secretary of St. Nazaire and later the divisional secretary on May 25, 1918. On November 28, 1918, he was made the regional secretary. As secretary, he oversaw the Y.M.C.A. activities. He left France on February 23, 1919, on furlough. File includes photos, letters, and newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: YMCA of the USA

Name: Ray D. Walston
Title: Ray D. Walston file
Description: File documenting the participation of Ray D. Watson in World War I. Walston enlisted on April 29, 1918, and was stationed at Camp Travis, Texas, with the 359th Infantry. He was sent overseas on June 19, 1918. He participated in the Battle of St. Mihiel and the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. He was hospitalized on November 1, 1918, in Fleury, France, for an operation after a wound in his arm and remained in the hospital in between the towns of Mesves and Bulcy, France, until January 25, 1919. Walston was sent back to the States on March 26, 1919, and discharged on April 21, 1919. File includes two surveys, a photo, RSVP card, envelope, and newspaper clippings. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Infantry, 359th
Topics: Walston, Ray D.; Saint-Mihiel, Battle of, Saint-Mihiel, France, 1918; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Brewer Wellington Ward
Title: Brewer Wellington Ward file
Description: File documenting the participation of Brewer Wellington Ward in World War I. Ward enlisted on June 19, 1917, and was first stationed at Yerba Buena Island in California. He joined Harvard University on July 10, 1917, and became a Radio Operator on August 1, 1918. He was stationed in San Francisco, New York City, and later on the S.S. West Indian. On Marcy 10, 1919, he transferred to Honolulu, Hawaii. Ward was discharged on September 9, 1919. File includes a survey, RSVP card, and letter.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Navy; Harvard University; United States. Naval Radio Service
Topics: Ward, Brewer Wellington; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Raymond Ford Ward
Title: Raymond Ford Ward file
Description: File documenting the participation of Raymond Ford Ward in World War I. Ward enlisted on May 19, 1918, and was stationed at Caswell, North Carolina, with the 5th Coast Artillery Corps. He was sent overseas on September 23, 1918. After the armistice was signed, he was transferred to the 54th Coast Artillery Corps and stationed in Angers, France. He was hospitalized at British Hospital no. 67 for influenza on October 14, 1918. On October 29, 1918, he was hospitalized in Cherbourg, France, for spinal meningitis. Ward returned to the States on March 6, 1919. File includes a survey and newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Coast Artillery Regiment, 5th; United States. Army. Coast Artillery Regiment, 54th
Topics: Ward, Raymond Ford; Influenza Epidemic, 1918-1919; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Rufus Olin Warner
Location: Great Lakes Naval Training Center (Great Lakes, Ill.)
Title: Rufus Olin Warner file
Description: File documenting the participation of Rufus Olin Warner in World War I. Warner was first stationed at the Great Lakes Naval Station in the Hospital Corps. He transferred to Portsmouth Naval Shipyard in New Hampshire on January 19, 1917. On November 23, 1917, he was stationed on the U.S.S. Montana as a pharmacists' mate. He became a Naval Reserve Line Officer on September 5, 1918, at Pelham Bay, New York. On November 12, 1918, he joined the Naval Academy at Annapolis, Maryland. Warner was released from active duty on February 2, 1919.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Navy; United States. Navy. Hospital Corps; Portsmouth Naval Shipyard (U.S.); United States. Naval Reserve; United States Naval Academy
Topics: Warner, Rufus Olin; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Irl Beam Warnock
Title: Irl Beam Warnock file
Description: File documenting the participation of Irl Beam Warnock in World War I. Warnock was drafted on September 18, 1917, and was stationed at Camp Dodge, Iowa, in the Medical Department. He was sent overseas on August 17, 1918, with Field Hospital no. 352 with the 313th Sanitary Train. He was stationed outside of Belfort, France. Warnock returned to the States on May 22, 1919. File includes a survey, RSVP card, letter, and newspaper clippings. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.

Name: Robert Glenn Washburn
Title: Robert Glenn Washburn file
Description: File documenting the participation of Robert Glenn Washburn in World War I. Washburn enlisted on June 28, 1917, and was stationed at Omaha, Nebraska, with the Aviation Section Signal Enlisted Reserve Corps. He joined the 54th Balloon Division at San Antonio, Texas, in April 1918. He later transferred to Camp Morrison, Virginia, and was discharged on December 27, 1918. File includes a survey, photo, letter, newspaper clippings, and Washburn's business card.

Name: Ferre Charles Watkins
Title: Ferre Charles Watkins file
Description: File documenting the participation of Ferre Charles Watkins in World War I. Watkins enlisted on May 17, 1917, and was stationed in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in the Officers Battalion on August 24, 1917. He joined the 31st Infantry at Camp Grant, Illinois, on August 15, 1917. He attended Harvard University's trench-warfare school on August 24, 1917, and then returned to Camp Grant on September 26, 1917. He was sent overseas on September 9, 1918, and participated in the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. He was stationed in Cubzac-les-Ponts, France, with the 356th Infantry on October 7, 1918. He returned to the States on May 27, 1919, and was discharged on June 23, 1919. File includes a survey, photo, letters, and newspaper clippings. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Infantry, 31st; Harvard University; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 356th
Topics: Watkins, Ferre C., 1893-1966; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Clyde I. West
Title: Clyde I. West file
Description: File documenting the participation of Clyde I. West in World War I. West enlisted on May 25, 1918, and was stationed at Camp Shelby, Mississippi. He was sent overseas on September 17, 1918, and was stationed at the University of Grenoble as an instructor and records clerk. According to the 1919 edition of the Index (Illinois State Normal University's yearbook), he was a part of the 151st Infantry. West returned to the States on July 18, 1919. File includes an RSVP card and letter. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.

Name: Bruce Elijah Wheeler
Title: Bruce Elijah Wheeler file
Description: File documenting the participation of Bruce Elijah Wheeler in World War I. Wheeler enlisted on August 1, 1918, and was first stationed at Camp Taylor, Kentucky, with the 159th Depot Brigade. He transferred to West Point, Kentucky, to join to 325th Field Artillery. He was sent overseas on September 9, 1918, and was stationed at Camp Winall Down in Winchester, England, then La Havre, France, until the Armistice was signed. He was at Camp De Souge, France, until he was sent home. Wheeler returned to the States on February 16, 1919, and was discharged on February 28, 1919. File includes a survey.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Depot Brigade, 159th; United States. Army. Field Artillery Regiment, 325th
Topics: Wheeler, Bruce Elijah; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Donald Dooley Whitcomb
Title: Donald Dooley Whitcomb file
Description: File documenting the participation of Donald Dooley Whitcomb in World War I. Whitcomb enlisted on May 23, 1917, and was first stationed in El Paso, Texas, with the 2nd Engineers. He was sent overseas on September 10, 1917, and was stationed in Sommedieue, France. He participated in the battles at the Toulon sector, the Aisne-Marne Offensive, in the Marbache sector, St. Mihiel, Chateau-Thierry, in the Champagne sector, and the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. He was hospitalized for influenza on October 29, 1918, in Vichy, France. Whitcomb returned to the States on August 12, 1919, and was discharged on August 15, 1919. File includes a survey, postcard, letters, newspaper clippings, and Whitcomb's marriage announcement.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Engineer Regiment, 2nd

Name: Leslie White
Title: Leslie White file
Description: File documenting the participation of Leslie White in World War I. White entered the Navy in August 1918, and was first stationed at Municipal Pier in Chicago. He was hospitalized for pneumonia from September 1918 until October 1918, when he was given thirty-day sick leave to recover. He was stationed on the U.S.S. Jamestown in December 1918, and transferred to Pelham Bay, New York, in January 1919. White was discharged on May 15, 1919. File includes newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Navy

Name: Clarence A. Whiteside
Title: Clarence A. Whiteside file
Description: File documenting the participation of Clarence A. Whiteside in World War I. Whiteside enlisted on April 29, 1918, and served with the 309th Machine Gun Battalion at Camp Dix, New Jersey. He was sent overseas on May 26, 1918, and was stationed at Le Wast and Hautecloque, France. He participated in the Battle of St. Mihiel and the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. After the armistice was signed, he was stationed in Cote-d'Or, France, and later joined the University Montpellier in France on March 4, 1919. He left for the States on July 9, 1919. File includes notes documenting his service and a photo.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Machine Gun Battalion, 309th; Université de Montpellier
Topics: Whiteside, Clarence A.; Saint-Mihiel, Battle of, Saint-Mihiel, France, 1918; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: William George Wiegand
Title: William George Wiegand file
Description: File documenting the participation of William George Wiegand in World War I. Wiegand enlisted on June 14, 1918, and was first stationed at Rahe's Automated Tractor School in Kansas City, Missouri. He joined the Motor Transport Corps 302nd Water Tank Train on August 17, 1918, at Camp Holabird, Maryland. He was hospitalized for influenza from September 25 to October 3, 1918, at Camp Upton, New York. He was sent overseas on November 3, 1918, and, after the armistice was signed, he was stationed in Pannes, France. He was hospitalized March 6 to March 13, 1919, in Dijon, France due to illness. He returned to the States on April 27, 1919, and received surgical treatment at Camp Grant, Illinois, on May 5, 1919. Wiegand was discharged on May 28, 1919. File includes a survey and photo.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Motor Transport Corps
Topics: Wiegand, William George; Influenza Epidemic, 1918-1919; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Topics: Wiegand, William George; Influenza Epidemic, 1918-1919; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: William George Wiegand
Title: William George Wiegand file
Description: File documenting the participation of William George Wiegand in World War I. Wiegand enlisted on June 14, 1918, and was first stationed at Rahe's Automated Tractor School in Kansas City, Missouri. He joined the Motor Transport Corps 302nd Water Tank Train on August 17, 1918, at Camp Holabird, Maryland. He was hospitalized for influenza from September 25 to October 3, 1918, at Camp Upton, New York. He was sent overseas on November 3, 1918, and, after the armistice was signed, he was stationed in Pannes, France. He was hospitalized March 6 to March 13, 1919, in Dijon, France due to illness. He returned to the States on April 27, 1919, and received surgical treatment at Camp Grant, Illinois, on May 5, 1919. Wiegand was discharged on May 28, 1919. File includes a survey and photo.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Motor Transport Corps
Topics: Wiegand, William George; Influenza Epidemic, 1918-1919; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Julius E. Wiemers
Title: Julius E. Wiemers file
Description: File documenting the participation of Julius E. Wiemers in World War I. Wiemers enlisted on July 24, 1918, and served at Scott Field, Illinois, with the 221st Aero Squadron. He was hospitalized from November 13 to November 27, 1919, for influenza. Wiemers was discharged on April 17, 1919. File includes a survey, photos, and a letter.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Air Service; United States. Army. Air Service. Aero Squadron, 221st

Name: Vernon Whitney Wieting
Title: Vernon Whitney Wieting file
Description: File documenting the participation of Vernon Whitney Wieting in World War I. Wieting enlisted on May 5, 1917, and was first stationed at Camp Parker, Illinois, with the 5th Illinois Infantry. He transferred to Camp Logan, Texas, to join the 124th Machine Gun Battalion. He was sent overseas on May 15, 1918, and participated in engagements at the Albert, France, and Warloy-Baillon, France, Sectors, as well as the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. After the armistice was signed, he was stationed in Waldbillig, Luxembourg. He was hospitalized at Bazoilles-sur-Meuse, France, from October 10, 1918, to January 17, 1919, for injuries sustained from powder burns on his face and shrapnel in his arm. Wieting returned to the States on May 16, 1919, and was discharged on May 30, 1919. File includes a survey, letter, and newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Illinois Infantry Regiment, 5th; United States. Army. Machine Gun Battalion, 124th
Topics: Wieting, Vernon Whitney; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Frank Grant Wiley
Title: Frank Grant Wiley file
Description: File documenting the participation of Frank Grant Wiley in World War I. Wiley was sent overseas on September 9, 1918. He taught mathematics at the army school in St. Nazaire, France, with the Headquarters Troop. Wiley returned to the States on July 11, 1919. File includes newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army
Topics: Wiley, Frant Grant; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Flavia Williams
Title: Flavia Williams file
Description: File documenting the participation of Flavia Williams in World War I. Williams entered the service on May 1, 1919, and was a nurse's aide in the Red Cross. She sailed to Siberia on May 10, 1919. She was stationed at Irkutsk, Siberia, and then transferred to Verkhne-Udinsk, Siberia, (renamed Ulan-Ude in 1934) on September 5, 1919. She returned to Irkutsk on October 25, 1919. Williams left for the States on February 5, 1920, and was discharged on February 20, 1920. File includes a survey, William's service record card, a receipt for mailing an insured package, letters, a note from William's mother documenting letters she has received from her, and a newspaper clipping. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.
Related organization/service branch: American National Red Cross
Topics: Williams, Flavia; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students
Genre/format: questionnaires; cards (information artifacts); receipts (financial records); letters (correspondence); newspaper clippings;

Name: Ira Dean Williams
Title: Ira Dean Williams file
Description: File documenting the participation of Ira Dean Williams in World War I. Williams enlisted in May 1917 and served with the 16th Infantry. He was sent overseas on June 27, 1917. He participated in the engagements at the sectors in Sommerviller, Ansauville & Cantigny, Soissons and Marne Offensive, Battle of St. Mihiel, Argonne-Meuse Offensive, Mouzon, and in early November 1918, in southwest Sedan, France. He was hospitalized until April 1919 from a gas attack and a leg injury from the engagement near Sedan. He left for the States on April 7, 1919. File includes letters. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 16th
Topics: Williams, Ira Dean; Saint-Mihiel, Battle of, Saint-Mihiel, France, 1918; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Donald H. Wilson
Title: Donald H. Wilson file
Description: File documenting the participation of Donald H. Wilson in World War I. Wilson enlisted on July 25, 1917, and first served with the 5th Illinois National Guard as a musician in Quincy, Illinois. He transferred to Camp Logan, Texas, to join the 129th Infantry. He was later a part of the 122nd Machine Gun Battalion and the 108th Engineers. He joined the 304th Cavalry and the 43rd Field Artillery Corps at Camp Stanley, Texas. Wilson was discharged on February 7, 1918. File includes a survey and letter.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; Illinois. National Guard; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 129th; United States. Army. Machine Gun Battalion, 122nd; United States. Army. Engineer Regiment, 129th; United States. Army. Engineer Regiment, 108th; United States. Army. Coast Artillery Regiment, 304th; United States. Army. Field Artillery Regiment, 43rd
Topics: Wilson, Donald H.; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Fremont Philip Wirth
Title: Fremont Philip Wirth file
Description: File documenting the participation of Fremont Philip Wirth in World War I. Wirth enlisted on May 15, 1918, and was first stationed at Camp Taylor, Kentucky, in the Officers' Training School. He transferred to Camp Sherman, Ohio, in the Infantry Development Battalion. Name: Orlo Wayne Woods
Title: Orlo Wayne Woods file
Description: File documenting the participation of Orlo Wayne Woods in World War I. Woods enlisted on July 25, 1918, and was stationed at Camp Logan, Texas, on September 13, 1917, with the 129th Infantry. He was sent overseas on May 10, 1918, and was stationed at U.S. Base Hospital no. 29 in London, England. He returned to the states on December 16, 1918. He was at General Hospital no. 28 at Fort Sheridan, Illinois, in June 1919. File includes letters. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.

Title: Carl Yeck file
Description: File includes notes documenting the participation of Carl Yeck in World War I. Name: Lee Owen Yoder
Title: Lee Owen Yoder file
Description: File documenting the participation of Lee Owen Yoder in World War I. Yoder enlisted on April 8, 1918, and first served at Waco, Texas, with the 33rd Aero Squadron. He joined the Meteorological Sector of the Signal Corps on May 23, 1918. On July 24, 1918, he transferred to College Station, Texas. He was sent overseas on September 22, 1918, and was stationed in Colombey-Les-Belles, France. He transferred to Nantes, France, on December 13, 1918. Yoder returned to the states on March 7, 1919, and was discharged on March 27, 1919. File includes a survey, name card, photos, RSVP card, letters, and newspaper clippings.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Air Service; United States. Army. Air Service. Aero Squadron, 33rd; United States. Army. Signal Corps; United States. Army. Meteorological Service
Topics: Yoder, Lee Owen; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Marion Amos York
Title: Marion Amos York file
Description: File documenting the participation of Marion Amos York in World War I. York enlisted on May 2, 1918, and first served at Camp MacArthur, Texas, with the 56th Infantry. He was sent overseas on August 2, 1918, with the 39th Infantry and participation in the Battle of St. Mihiel, engagements at the Toulon Sector, and the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. He was hospitalized in Mesves, France, from October 8 to November 16, 1918, for a wound. After the armistice was signed, he was stationed in the Eifel region of Germany. York returned to the States on August 6, 1919, and was discharged on August 13, 1919. File includes a survey.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 56th; United States. Army. Infantry Regiment, 39th
Topics: York, Marion Amos; Saint-Mihiel, Battle of, Saint-Mihiel, France, 1918; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: Eugene Edward Young
Title: Eugene Edward Young file
Description: File documenting the participation of Eugene Edward Young in World War I. Young enlisted on December 11, 1917, and served with the 60th Coast Artillery Corps at Fort Monroe, Virginia. He was sent to France on April 22, 1918, and participated in the Meuse-Argonne Offensive and the Battle of St. Mihiel. He was hospitalized from November 25, 1918, to January 1, 1919, in Donjeux, France, for diphtheria. Young returned to the States on February 4, 1918, and was discharged on March 13, 1919. File includes a survey and photo. Description supplemented by information from Fold3.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Army; United States. Army. Coast Artillery Regiment, 60th
Topics: Young, Eugene Edward; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students

Name: William Asberry Zook
Title: William Asberry Zook file
Description: File documenting the participation of William Asberry Zook in World War I. Zook enlisted on May 7, 1917, and was first stationed at the Marine Corps Recruit Depot at Parris Island, South Carolina with the 23rd Company of the 6th Marines. He transferred to Quantico, Virginia, on July 30, 1917, to join the 82nd Company of the 6th Marines. He was sent overseas on October 24, 1917. He was first stationed at Bordeaux, France, then transferred to an unknown town in France on December 24, 1917, then to Nanteuil-sur-Marne, France, on July 14, 1918, and later to Langres, France, on August 16, 1918. He participated in engagements at the Verdun Sector, the Aisne-Marne Defensive, the Battle of Chateau-Thierry, Aisne-Marne Offensive, Marbache Sector, the Battle of St. Mihiel, and the Meuse-Argonne Offensive. After the armistice was signed, he was stationed in Leutesdorf, Germany. Zook returned to the States on August 9, 1919, and was discharged on August 15, 1919.
Related organization/service branch: United States. Marine Corps; Parris Island (S.C. : Recruit depot); United States. Marine Corps. Marine Regiment, 6th
Topics: Zook, William Asberry; Verdun, Battle of, Verdun, France, 1916; Ch├óteau-Thierry, Battle of, Ch├óteau-Thierry, France, 1918; Aisne, Battle of the, France, 1918; Marne, 2nd Battle of the, France, 1918; Saint-Mihiel, Battle of, Saint-Mihiel, France, 1918; Argonne, Battle of the, France, 1918; World War, 1914-1918; Illinois State Normal University--Students
